item.title: Dalai-Lama | India remains on the sidelines of succession
item.description: The Indian government assured Friday that it will remain on the sidelines of the choice of Dalai-Lama successor, contrasting with China who rejects the process and considers the Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist of the annexed region. In a statement about Dalai-Lama's succession plan, the Narendra Moder's Foreign Ministry of Government states that he will not take “any position” on issues of faith. "The government of India does not take any position or pronouncement on issues related to beliefs and practices of faith and religion," said Ministry spokesman Randhir Jaiswal, in response to media questions about the recent announcement of the Tibetan spiritual leader. The country "has always defended religious freedom to everyone in India and will continue to do so," he said. On Thursday, the Indian minister of minority affairs, Kiren Rijiju, told local media that the decision would be exclusively to the Buddhist leader. "All those who follow Dalai-Lama believe that reincarnation must be decided according to the established conventions and Dalai-Lama's own wishes. No one else has the right to decide, except for him and the current conventions," said Rijiju. China reiterated on Wednesday that Dalai-Lama's successor should be "approved by the central government." "The reincarnation of great Buddhists, such as Dalai-Lama and Panchen Lama, should be determined by draw through the golden ballot box and later approved by the central government," said China's Ministry of Foreign Ministry spokesman Mao Ning.

item.title: DSAT | Lam hin San liability is a test to the government
item.description: Following the disclosure of the audit Commissioner report highlighted the lack of inspection to Radio Taxi and the breach of the requirements set forth in the concession contract, criticism of the Director of Services for Traffic Affairs (DSAT) Lam Hin San was multiplied. The president of the Macao Synergy Association, Johnson Ian, wrote an opinion article, published in the newspaper Sou Pou, to relate Lam Hin San's position in the context of the remodeling of management directors and departments recently announced. The candidate for deputy for the list led by Ron Lam considers that the population is more focused on the need to hold the DSAT director responsible than the remodeling itself. To confirm the rumor that Lam Hin San could be transferred to the port administration company, Johnson Ian argues that the departure of DSAT without liability, to occupy another position with a high salary, will not be well regarded by the population. The candidate for deputy goes further and indicates that the situation of DSAT is a political test for the new government, even more at a time when changes to the statutes of management and leadership personnel is under analysis in the specialty in the Legislative Assembly. As such, Johnson Ian considers that the population of Macao will soon know if the Sam Hou Fai executive takes seriously the holders of high management positions, or whether the theme is just a political slogan. Rise in arrow "For many years that the bureaucratic culture of Macao has not eliminated the bad and retains the good, does not reward the diligents and punishes the lazy, nor reward the most competent. Instead, it is more worth knowing people in high positions, than having professional knowledge, and liability is a mere formality," said the candidate of the deputy. Johnson Ian also states that the only career mobility for a certain level is hierarchical climb, rise fostered by a professional bureaucratic protection environment and that the admission of failures is rare, which prevents corrections. In addition, the associative leader regrets that social voices that dare criticize politicians are labeled as agitators who only cause problems.

item.title: Heat | High temperatures alert leads to the reopening of the shelter center
item.description: The Institute of Social Action (IAS) opened on Saturday the summer shelter center, on East Street of Ilha Verde, 34, after the meteorological and geophysical services (SMG) issued an orange warning for high temperatures, the first of the year after several yellow alerts (lower degree of severity). Authorities predicted yesterday that the high temperatures continue today to affect the territory, but that time heat would slow throughout the week. IAS indicated that the shelter will remain open until the temperature lowers and appeals to the population to be aware of the physical situation of the elderly, chronic patients and people with physical weaknesses, taking measures against heat and health effects. Temperatures arrived yesterday at 36 degrees, and the authorities warned of the need for hydration, avoid direct and prolonged exposure to the sun and wearing wide and thin clothes of light in -open activities. In addition to the heat, the SMG warned the population yesterday for the poor air quality, which reached the “unhealthy” degree, advising the reduction to maximum activities abroad.

item.title: Cape Verde | Macau Legend says he has alternative to Hotel-Casino
item.description:
While the reversal process of the company linked to David Chow, Macau Legend will have a “last opportunity” to find a solution for the Praia's unfinished casino hotel
The Cape Verde Internal Affairs Minister told Lusa that the government will give Macau Legend a "last opportunity", which promised "an alternative" for the beach-casino hotel on the beach. "The entrepreneur has had several opportunities and has this last opportunity. He says he will have an alternative and the government is awaiting the presentation of this alternative, while the reversal process takes place" of the project, said Paulo Rocha in an interview with Lusa. In November, the Cape Verde authorities began a reversal process of the Hotel Casino and other unfinished works of Macau Legend, at Santa Maria Island and Gamboa Sea Marítimo, in Praia City. Paulo Rocha said that the Cape Verdean executive gave the company founded by David Chow Kam Fai 60 days to present a new proposal to conclude the project, but admitted not to know when this period "started to count". "If it does not present, within the period that was given, the reversal process will be concluded and then the government will look for others, likely, any investors," said the minister, during a visit to Macao. Stop everything Currently, there are only guards at the venue, an area of ​​about 160,000 square meters, which includes the partially sparkled Santa Maria islet and, a paved bridge of a few meters that connects it to a building of about eight floors, empty and sealed with tails. "The works have been stopped for a long time, have been halfway through there is no movement in that construction shipyard and the government intends to see it resolved. In one way or another," said Rocha. The executive said in November that he gave Macao Legend "all opportunities to resume works or to negotiate the sale of actions or the assignment of his contractual position to a potential interested in continuing the project" but no alternatives were presented. "The project remains important, remains strategic for the city of Praia, for Cape Verde, and the government is interested in finding a solution," said the minister. In 2015, David Chow signed an agreement for an investment of 250 million euros. After revisions, about six years ago, the conclusion of the first phase was scheduled for 2021. At the end of 2023, Macau Legend President Li Chu Kwan said the group intended to close the projects in Cape Verde and Cambodia by 2025. On March 28, Macau Legend announced losses of $ 45.9 million from Hong Kong in 2024, in part due to the reversal of the beach hotel on the beach. The operator reiterated that she was “taking the necessary measures to safeguard the group's interests (…), including exploring all available options to contest the decision” regarding the reversal process of the Cape Verdean Hotel Casino. On the other hand, Macao Legend admitted to "significant doubts about the group's ability to continue in activity" due to total dollar $ 2.51 billion debts.

item.title: Advertising | Government wants to change law and legislate “influencers”
item.description:
Macau authorities proposed for the first time regulating the activity of digital influencers, including 'live marketing', which involves real -time interaction with the public, changing a law of time from Portuguese administration
About 36 years after the entry into force of the Advertising Acting Law, the government is preparing to update the legislation, which will regulate the activities of digital influencers and live marketing, in which content creators interact or sell first-time products, with real-time interaction with the public. Plated last Friday, the 30-day public consultation, which will take place until August 2, on the amendments to the law. During this period, the government will organize five consultation sessions, where legal concepts and definitions will be discussed and clarified the terms on inspection regimes and administrative sanctions. "It is suggested to clarify that participants in online promotion activities and 'live marketing', such as advertisers, advertising agencies, platform owners and presenters, are subject to the advertising activity law and must fulfill their provisions when their acts are advertising," said the director of Economics and Technological Development Services (DSEDT) at a press conference. The current law of advertising activity has been in force since 1989, Yau Yun Wah indicated that, considering the changes in the economic activity of the various sectors and technological evolution, "the contents, forms of dissemination and means used in current advertising are significantly different from those of the past." According to the proposal, influencers should first use the products they support, in order to ensure compliance with the “veracity” requirement of the law. They may also “have to provide proofs of their support under a 'obligation of cooperation',” said Yau Yun Wah. Own characteristics "We hope that in the future, 'advertising' [influencers] will be clearly identified in the announcements and that, in case of complaints or false allegations, legal measures may be taken," he added. The official also clarified that if companies hire influencers from outside Macao to promote products, they must obtain a work permit for them. The DSEDT director also claimed to expect the future law to allow the increase in advertising on the streets of Macau. "Through the prior authorization regime we hope that the advertising sector may have more relief and develop," said Yau Yun Wah, adding last year's advertising requests were more than 4,000. Lack of scope Deputy Ron Lam argued that changes to the advertising activity law, currently in public consultation, are not comprehensive enough, unable to cover some areas. According to the citizen newspaper, Ron Lam pointed out that despite the government's proposal to change the law to include the simplification of procedures and bring new definitions to advertising online, there are no definitions or regulations on new types of advertising, such as advertising projected by lighting or real estate. The deputy says he does not understand why the executive's proposal does not include, in real estate advertising, the advertising that is made to the vehicle parking lot. The legislator understands that there must be a transitional period and greater dissemination of information, given that the changes in the advertising regime cover several professional areas. JL /LUSA

item.title: Women | Deputy wants old prison as a base of patriotism
item.description:
Deputy Wong Kit Cheng, linked to the Women's Association, intends to transform the old prison into a base of nationalism. Wong believes this would be a good way to promote Coloane's economy
Wong Kit Cheng defends the transformation of the facilities of the old Coloane prison into a "base" to promote patriotism among the local population. The idea was released through a written interpellation of the deputy linked to the Women's Association. "Coloane's arrest is a witness to the history of correctional services, but it is also a land with an area of ​​18,000 square meters. It is a large building, which is not very common in Coloane, an area where there is lack of land, but also deserves to be revitalized," he began by indicating the deputy. "In fact, the revitalization of military, police or arrest facilities is common in other zones. For example, the old site of the Liugongdao Maritime Office and the Torpedo Factory in the city of Wehai, in Shandong Province, were turned into a broad national security exhibition center," said the deputy. Wong Kit Cheng also referred to the example of Hong Kong, where Victoria prison was transformed into a space with galleries and exposure zones open to the public. Promote the economy From the perspective of the deputy, the preservation of the historical site is still a way of promoting Coloane's economy: “In the future, if Colaane's arrest can be reused, the historical, cultural and correctional importance of the building can be used in the service of national security education, with the creation of immersive experiences, special games and commercial complexes,” he suggested. Wong also pointed out that reuse can “bring a new vitality to the community” by Coloane and promote the “development of cultural tourism and the protection of historical heritage”. "Since the land of Coloane's prison belongs to the government, what are the plans for the use of space and what plans will be followed to meet residents' expectations, while betting on Coloane's long -term development," he asked. “When will there be conditions to announce the land development plan?” He added. Assuming that the site should be transformed into a base of patriotism, and a “national security defense line”, Wong also questions the executive if the examples of various interior locations in the exposed materials level and will create permanent exhibitions on the subject. In addition to these aspects, Wong asks the government to present a calendar for the transformation of the place to the base that it considers fundamental to the MSAR.

item.title: AL | Deputies want to ban signs and implement suspensions
item.description:
The changes proposed by a group of legislators led by Kou Hoi in include the loss of office to any deputy sentenced to at least 30 days in prison inside or outside the Mand
In a little over a month of the Legislative Assembly vacation, and two months from legislative elections, a group of deputies wants to change the rules of hemiciclo to ban the display of signs in meetings, regulate the clothing of deputies, change the rules of mandate losses, and create a suspension system for those who reveal the content of what is discussed in the commissions. The amendments to review the statute of the deputies and the Legislative Assembly Regiment came from a group of nine deputies led by the President of the Legislative Assembly, Kou Hoi In, and the documents do not allow to identify the rest. At the proposal of loss of mandate, it is intended to apply to deputies convicted of a crime with a 30 -day arrest. For the loss of the mandate, the crimes contain on or outside the MSAR, and Parliament wants to be able to make the decision based on any document that it considers relevant, even if it is not official. The new statute provides for the police call to remove the deputy to whom the mandate was suspended, in the case of not leaving the plenary room. Regarding the suspension of the mandate of deputies, Kou wants the visited to become deprived of the monthly remuneration, contrary to what is currently happening. In addition, the suspension can be applied if there is “criminal proceedings” or “serious violation of the duties of deputies”. The president of AL will also be able to suspend any deputy suspected of revealing the content of the meetings at the closed door. Controlled clothes The group of deputies also aims to prohibit at meetings the use of "clothing" or "materials with offensive content or political provocation." Deputies who proposed the amendments consider that the prohibition “in no way interferes with the rights of deputies” because “they can express any opinions”, according to the Rules. The duties of the deputies will also be changed to consecrate the "Macau governed by patriots" policy, but also to oblige deputies to participate in meetings with voting and to be provided for conflicts of interests that prevent deputies from participating in voting in which their impartiality may be concerned. Among the various changes, deputies also want to self-impeders to submit proposals for public debates on issues considered in the government area.

item.title: BRICS | Seventh Cimeira ends today with focus on Trump's fares
item.description:
Since Saturday, leaders of the countries that are part of the BRICS Group have been gathered in Rio de Janeiro for another summit designed to think about the reform of institutions and inclusion of more emerging economies, as well as the fight against Trump's rates. Highlight for the absences of Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin
Since Saturday, Rio de Janeiro hosts the BRICS Group leaders, which ends today. The first day was based on the dialogue around the ambition of emerging economies to reform international institutions and the defense of multilateralism. "I think the main message is this: at the time of so many international crises, conflicts, we are experiencing a succession of conflicts that only increase from year to year, having a set of countries reaffirming the power of diplomacy, cooperation, the need to act jointly, to solve the problems of the population and not to generate more destruction, such as conflicts, it is an opportunity that we always have to take advantage of," Lyrio, guide of discussions and agreements of heads of state at the conference, designated by the Brazilian presidency of the BRICS. In all, about 30 countries and nine international organizations have been present, with the Brazilian head of state, Lula da Silva leading the meeting, which has Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, South African President Cyril Ramaphosa, Angola President and African Union, the Secretary-General of United Nations, António Guterres, among others. The main absences are Russian and Chinese heads of state, two BRICS founding countries. Vladimir Putin, the target of a warrant of detention issued by the International Criminal Court (ICC), on suspicion of illegal deportation of Ukrainian children to Russia, will only participate in video conferencing. Chinese Prime Minister Li Qiang and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov will be the representatives of the two founding countries of the group, which represents more than 40 percent of the global population and more than 35 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) worldwide. From China with Love According to Chinese state agency Xinhua, Chinese prime minister promised to “expand cooperation with Brazil” in the areas of “digital and aerospace economy”. Li Qiang spoke on Saturday, as part of a meeting with Lula da Silva, noting that the country intends to “work with Brazil to take advantage of each other and expand cooperation in areas such as digital economy, green economy, scientific and technological and aerospace innovation”. Xinhua quotes words from Li Qiang, who referred to the fact that “China is ready to work with Brazil to continue efforts to enrich the dimensions of bilateral relations and achieve more concrete results in cooperation in order to provide more benefits to both peoples”. One of the points out of this meeting was the realization in 2026 of the year of China-Brazil culture, which provides for an intensification in cooperation in areas such as “education, youth and health”, in order to facilitate “more exchanges between peoples and strengthen public support to China-Brazil's friendship and cooperation”. “China is willing to work with Brazil to further consolidate and deepen bilateral cooperation in trade, finance and infrastructure development within the high quality cooperation of Belt And Road [track and route]”, the Chinese prime minister, who did not forget the great flag of this BRICS Summit: multilateralism. Thus, I read Qiang considered “the two countries as fierce defenders of multilateralism and free trade”, saying that “China is willing to improve communication and coordination with Brazil in multilateral structures such as the United Nations, BRICS and G20, work in union with developing countries to promote an equal and ordered multipolar world and universally beneficial and inclusive economic globalization, and provide more certainty and stability to the world. ” On the other hand, Lula da Silva said that "Brazil is willing to deepen communication and multilateral coordination with China, to oppose unilateralism and defend multilateralism and free trade in order to promote peace and world development." After the meeting between the two leaders, “cooperation documents in areas such as tax and financial matters, artificial intelligence, alignment of development strategies and aerospace” were signed.
Cuba's debut Cuba President Miguel Díaz-Canel also participates in the 17th BRICS Summit, being the first time Cuba has associated with this geopolitical and economic cooperation group. Under the motto “reinforcing cooperation in the global south for more inclusive and sustainable governance”, the BRICS Summit's agenda comprises two central axes: the consolidation of cooperation between the global southern countries and the promotion of reforms in international governance mechanisms. Created in 2009 throughout Brazil, Russia, India and China, BRICS admitted South Africa two years later and, since last year, integrates six new effective members: Egypt, United Arab Emirates, Ethiopia, Iran, Indonesia and Saudi Arabia. Brazil invited to this summit leaders from various Latin American countries, including Mexico, Colombia, Uruguay and Chile. The statute of associate, which takes Cuba to Rio de Janeiro, was approved in October 2024 during the summit of the group held in the Russian city of Kazan, which was made official in 2025, recalled the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Caribbean country. In addition to geopolitical issues, BRICS have sought in Rio de Janeiro in the organization's economic weight, namely in the financial domain, in which they have been looking for a dollar for years for trade in the group. The host president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, president of Brazil, stressed last Friday the importance of a mechanism with these characteristics, recognizing, however, that the current international political context is "complicated". What is on the agenda On the first day, the heads of state and government of the BRICS participated in two plenary sessions, particularly on "peace and safety and reform of global governance" and the second relative to the strengthening of multilateralism, economic and financial affairs and artificial intelligence. " In the latter, the revision of the ACCIORARY participation in the World Bank, the realignment of IMF shares [International Monetary Fund] and the increase in the representation of developing countries in leadership positions in international financial institutions and the importance of reforming the UN Security Council. In addition, as it has been happening during the BRICS ministerial meetings over the past few months, an increase in unilateral unilateral unilateral protectionist measures should be made in reference to the measures announced by the President of the United States, Donald Trump; as well as an appeal to reinforce the use of local currencies in trade between the bloc countries. Today the plenary session will be on “Environment, COP30 and Global Health”. The term BRIC was created by a Goldman Sachs analyst to refer to emerging economies who began to stand out worldwide beyond the US, with the BRICS first gathered at the level of heads in 2009. This is the first meeting that brings together the new group configuration with 11 member countries. Brazil has mobilized about 20,000 military personnel, as well as fighters with missiles, anti-drug systems and elite shooters to ensure the safety of the event. The safety operation, called Operational Command Redeemer Set, also provides for the use of 300 vehicles, 38 armored vehicles, 18 boats and eight helicopters.

item.title: We are! | Portuguese theater from Lisbon to Macau with “Júlio César”
item.description:
“Júlio César” is the play of the Chapitô Company, based in Lisbon, chosen to come to Macau in September. Also noteworthy is for the holding of physical and visual theater workshops in connection with the community, in a Somos initiative! - Portuguese Language Communication Association
September marks the arrival of an important Portuguese group linked to the circus arts and has been developing community connection projects in Lisbon for many years, receiving students and all people interested in their cultural offer. This group is the Chapitô Company, which thanks to Somos's initiative! - ACLP (Portuguese Language Communication Association), brings Macau, between September 20 and 23, the play “Júlio César” and the holding of physical and visual theater workshops, open to participants with or without experience in theater. The play “Júlio César” takes the stage of the Black Box I of the Cultural Center of Macau, on September 20, at 20h. This is the 39th collective creation of the company, and Chapitô was inspired, according to a note from Somos! - ACLP, "in life and historical events around Julius Caesar, exploring comedy as a language to reinvent history." And virtuous people who do what has to be done. Physical theater In Chapitô, a project led by Maria Teresa Ricou, they are “faithful to the physical theater style”, where “actors use the body, movement and gesture to create characters and transmit emotions universally, allowing an accessible experience to different audiences”. In Macao, and at the end of “Júlio César”, Chapitô Company will provide conversation and debate sessions, “promoting direct cultural exchange between artists and the audience thus leading to an exchange of ideas and reflections on the present theatrical experience”. The piece will be presented in Portuguese and subtitled in Chinese with approximately 90 minutes without break. Tickets have a value of 200 MOP and can already be purchased through Macauticket. To learn On September 21, 22 and 23, the Chapitô team presents, at Casa Garden, the physical and visual theater workshops, which aim to “explore improvisation techniques, character creation and nonverbal communication, using the body as a central tool for artistic and narrative expression”. There are in these sessions a division into three themes - body, space and improvisation; Gestural characters and archetypes; and dramatic game and creative improvisation, being the sessions led by trainers Jorge Cruz, Pedro Diogo and Susana Nunes. The workshops are taught in English with translation to Chinese and with a maximum capacity of 20 participants. Founded in 1996, the Chapitô Company is recognized for its multidisciplinary work, based on physical theater and communication through gesture and image. Still according to Somos! -ACLP, the performance of the show “Júlio César” and the physical and visual theater workshops, in Macao, “participants have the opportunity to explore the possibilities of interaction and fusion between different forms of artistic expression”, revealing to the public of Macau “the methodologies and the artistic vision of the Chapitô Company”. Thus, the association understands, “this experience can inspire new approaches and ideas of cultural exchange”.

item.title: Japan ready for all scenarios on tariffs
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigero Ishiba said on Sunday that the country is ready to “stay firm” and is prepared for all possible tariff scenarios that may result from commercial negotiations with the United States. Speaking on the "Sunday News, The Prime" program of the Japanese television channel Fuji TV, the ruler stressed the determination of Tokyo in negotiating the application of null customs rights - Zero tariff - in the automotive industry sector. Shigeru Ishiba also recalled that Japan is the largest foreign direct investor in the United States and the largest job creator in the world's largest economy. Japan's main commercial negotiator, Ryosi Akazawa, announced this Saturday that he maintained two telephone meetings with United States Secretary of Commerce, Howard Lutnick, to discuss customs rights, at a time of July 9 to impose the increase in rates by Washington. Akazawa and Lutnick spoke for 45 minutes on Thursday and for about an hour on Saturday, reaffirmed their positions on United States customs rights and “proceeded to exchange in-depth points,” according to a statement from the Japanese government secretariat. The parties will continue to coordinate, it adds in the statement. Written letters The phone calls took place at a time when a 10 percent rate of Japan sales to the United States is expected to return to 24 percent on July 9, if the tariff agreement is not closed. US President Donald Trump announced on Friday that he signed 12 letters, which will be sent this Monday to inform the commercial partners of the new customs of the United States about their exports to the US, which will begin to be applied next August 1st. Trump did not specify which countries will receive the letters. In addition to the broader tariffs, as with other countries, Japan is also subject to a 25 percent rate on the importation of automobiles and automotive components by the US and a 50 percent rate on steel and aluminum.

He was a descendant prince of the Song Dynasty, but he served the Mongols Yuan Dynasty as an official at the Hanlin Academy. As a painter, he specializes in the representation of horses and used recreating themes and styles of the old masters, with simple colors to make the landscapes. By Meng Tian, ​​a military commander of the Qin Dynasty. However, it is perceived by the painted vessels of different neolithic cultures, which must have existed for at least five thousand years. Therefore, Meng Tian will be linked, not to the invention, but to the improvement of brushes. Also the city of Huzhou is not the real place of production of the best brushes, but has won this title since in ancient times Shanlian, in the municipality of Wuxing, province of Zhejiang, was over his jurisdiction. The handwriting brushes made had their heyday during the Yuan Dynasty and are still considered among the best in all of China. Four steps are required to manufacture the HU brush, and the coat of the rabbit, the fingernail and the goat hair is used. After the fat is removed with tire juice, the hair is cut into equal sizes and enter a solution to clean them. They are then united at the base with arabic gum and after drying, united with a tile that unites them to the bamboo. With the brush made in its structure, the other phase of the process is passed. The hair is bumped to a porridge made of algae to put them together and with the wire wrapped a tip is created, the most important part of the brush. This wire that goes through the hair, on a lap gives the cone shape and also serves to remove the excess of the agglutinator papa. With extreme patience and skill, the brushes are clean, rounded, creating a tip, with good elasticity. Then the brush, ready, passes to the hands of another employee, where in the bamboo cable are recorded the characters Tian Kuan Trade Mark, which replaced the old “double goat” brand. The goat hair (HAO) brushes (HAO) are soft and serve to write small characters, rabbit hair are hard and those of the fingernail are between the two, with great elasticity for the handwriting of large characters. Sometimes a mixture of different hair is made, using those of other animals. There are brushes of all kinds of sizes, serving some to paint and others to call. The best for Chinese handwriting are the rabbit and goat hair mix. HU brushes were widely used in the imperial court. In the other part of the museum is the painter's room Zhao Mengfu with its utensils and some works, where the recorded stones are not lacking. Although the museum has a sales section, after leaving the museum and already on the street, a set of stores is dedicated to the sale of products for Chinese painting. Leaving the brushes, we visited the market and crossing a wooden bridge in Zig-Zag, we traveled another old part of the city. item.title: Cape Verde | Évora family, between Macau and the rest of the world
item.description:
Tomorrow are 50 years of Cape Verde's independence, the country from which the first levada of the Évora family came out in the 1940s, towards Macao, where he won roots. Nowadays, only one member of the family remains in the territory, the cardiologist Mário Évora
There were once a dozen Évoras in Macao, where they arrived in the 1940s, but only Mario Évora resists, with the family repeating the migrations that mark both Cape Verde and the Macanese. "We have been between eight and ten Évoras in Macau," Sports Medicine expert Humberto Évora told Lusa from Lisbon, where he has lived since he renovated. The maternal grandparents of Humberto (the last of the family to be born in Cape Verde) and Mário (the first to be born in Macau) arrived in the east in the late 1940s, with five of the couple's six children. A year later, the daughter who had stayed with her husband in Cape Verde came to Macau, already with baby Humberto. The initial plan was for two years, but the couple ended up three decades and have three more children: Mario, Rui and Maria Helena. In 1971, it was the turn of Humberto and Mário to leave to study medicine in Lisbon, but not without a great fright linked to the colonial war that had lasted a decade ago. "As we went to the university we could postpone military inspection, but the papers did not come from Macao and we risk being considered refractory," said Humberto. The situation resolved, but Mario admitted to Lusa the fear of the mobilization. "We had this persecution, we had to go through the year not to go with the sides in the war," he explained. “The Shock” in Lisbon Upon arrival in Lisbon, “we were soon welcomed and integrated into the Cape Verdean student community,” said Humberto, at a time of student agitation and politics. "There were periods when it was almost daily, manifestations of students against the regime, the shock police enter the canteen inside and give some suckling," said Mario. Humberto admitted that "it was a shock, for those who came from Macau, where there was little political culture and the colonial war was seen as a struggle against terrorists." In a summer, the young man, who was integrated into a Cape Verdean group of intervention music, left with a friend "to the overseas ride out of guitar on his back." “I always remember the first time in France, that I saw the colonial war described on the contrary on television, the struggle for the liberation of a colonial power of occupation,” said Humberto. Independence When the two brothers finished the medical course, the independence of Cape Verde, on July 5, 1975, led them to the root return. "There was a movement of many of our colleagues to contribute to a new country, which was beginning to take the first steps," said Mario, then a formed cardiologist. Also because, recalled Humberto, some of the friends of Lisbon had, however, became members of the Government of Cape Verde. "There was this possibility, but the return to Macao, a place where it had spent so long, was natural," he explained. “I was born in Cape Verde, I spent part of my life in Portugal, I grew up in Macao, I am also Macaense. I am a citizen of the world,” said Humberto. Macanese are a Euro-Asian community, most of which Lusodescendants, with roots in Macau, although many have emigrated, due to the economic situation or fear created by the transition from Portugal Administration to China in 1999. From the Évora brothers, Rui, engineer, left before the transition to Cape Verde, where he even worked on the project of the Hotel-Casino that Macau's businessman David Chow built on the beach, but was inaugurated. The younger sister, Maria Helena, a documentary science expert who has even worked in the Macao Historical Archive, is currently in the City Council of Oeiras. The children “are all out” between the United Kingdom, Cape Verde and Portugal, said Mario. "Now the world is smaller and it is going where there are opportunities," he said. Humberto also faces migrations "as a natural process, not only for Cape Verdeans, but even to the Macanese." Nothing that has prevented the two brothers from keeping their ties with the archipelago. Humberto divides the time between Portugal and Cape Verde, and has been the official doctor of Cape Verdean sports for decades to the main international competitions. Mario was one of the founders-and president for ten years-of the Macau-Cabo Green Friendship Association. "We had here Ildo Lobo, Tito Paris, and my cousin," said the cardiologist, before taking a break and adds, with a smile: "Cesaria Évora."

item.title: WHO | Study reveals that one in six people in the world feels
item.description:
A World Health Organization report states that loneliness is a growing problem. Based on a study conducted between 2014 and 2023, the document concluded that one in six people in the world feel alone, with emphasis on young people from 13 to 29 years old. The Southeast Asian region has, however, less problematic values
More and more is spoken of the devastating impact of loneliness as a potentializing cause of diseases. This time, a report from the World Health Organization (WHO), released on Monday and carried out by the Social Connection Commission, brings data on the problem, concluding that one in six people say he feels alone, a state that is not synonymous with being alone. Moreover, the problem is greater in younger ones, because one in five says it feels alone, which shows that one fifth of the world's population between 13 and 29 years old says it feels loneliness. The study, entitled “From Solitude to Social Connection - tracing a path to healthier societies: WHO Commission on Social Connection Commission”, focuses on 2013 and 2024, thus encompassing the pandemic, a period when most of the world populations faced confinement periods, some of them alone in their dwellings. The study was sent to journalists from 194 WHO member countries, and the data were dealt with in line with other works already done on the subject and with the support of experts from around the world, including from China. Bin Yu, from the Medical College Tianjin University, was one of the project participants. The report points out that between 2014 and 2023 "it is estimated that 16 percent of people around the world-one in six-felt loneliness," something that "affects all ages and regions." However, it is a “more common feeling among adolescents and young adults”, with a rate of 20.9 percent of young people between 13 and 17 years old, while the rate reduces slightly to 17.4 percent in the case of young adults from 18 to 29 years. The feeling of loneliness "decreases with age", and is also "more common in low-income countries, where almost one in four people (24 percent) claimed to feel lonely." The WHO study also points out that “the highest rates are in the WHO African region”, with 24 percent; Following the regions of the eastern Mediterranean (21 percent), and in Southeast Asia this feeling is less felt by respondents, registering only 18 percent. "The European region has the lowest rate, with about ten percent," says WHO, which distinguishes loneliness of social isolation. In this field, “data is more limited”, but the isolation of the elderly stands out. "Estimates suggest that 25-34 percent of the elderly are socially isolated," it is data on the years between 1990 and 2022. When it comes to adulthood, from 30 to 59 years, the percentage of people who feel only low to 15.1 percent, and in people 60 years or older, with 11.8 percent. Regarding gender, “estimated rates of loneliness in women and men are similar (16.1 and 15.4 percent, respectively), with the highest estimated differences between adolescents (24.3 percent between women and 17.2 percent between men) and the elderly (13 percent between women and 9.9 percent among men)”. Who else feels The report states that nowadays “social disconnection is widespread in all regions and in all age groups”, with consequences that are “serious and underestimated, affecting mortality, physical and mental health, well-being, education, economy and society in general”. "Its widespread occurrence and its serious consequences make it a serious issue of global public health," it is mentioned. And who feels more alone? The WHO highlights “marginalized groups”, namely “people with disabilities, lesbians, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer (or sometimes in question) and other individuals (LGBTIQ+) and migrants”. These people “are more likely to feel loneliness and isolation than other groups”, making it the caveat that “previous data are too limited to determine whether social isolation and solitude rates have increased or decreased”. In the case of disabled people, scenarios persist such as being unable to “access social facilities and take advantage of opportunities due to physical barriers in buildings, limited access to transportation and lack of affordable information and communication, while others face structural stigma that limits their job opportunities or other sociocultural barriers that lead to lower level of education, less stable relationships and more precarious housing conditions”. "Many factors" are identified that lead people to feel alone, namely "modernization, industrialization and technological changes", and may be "responsible for what, often, it is presumed to be an increase in social isolation and loneliness, but most remain without proof." "We know that certain factors increase the risk of individuals suffering from social disconnection. These include poor physical or mental health (especially depression), personality traits such as neuroticism, not having a partner or being single, living alone and characteristics of the built environment, such as poor access to public transport. The impact of digital technology is not yet clear, but experts recommend caution, especially to protect the mental health and well-being of young people." study. The WHO highlights, throughout the text, how it is difficult to quantify feelings of loneliness, being relatively recent this type of definitions and, above all, differentiation between the feeling of feeling alone and being effectively only. The report includes testimonies from people from various countries and cultures that describe that, even though they are with a partner or friends, they feel alone in a scenario caused by many factors. In the case of young people, "the realization of high loneliness rates between adolescents is consistent with the results of previous research, although the result may be subject to both developmental and methodological considerations." “As loneliness results from a perceived discrepancy between real and desired or expected social connections, the highest rate in adolescence can be due to higher expectations of social connections during the development phase, which is marked by significant emotional and psychological changes. The elderly report comparatively greater satisfaction with their social relations. According to these estimates, the elderly have the lowest loneliness rates, which contradicts previous studies that enhanced the elderly as the age range with some of the highest rates. This may be due to the limited availability and quality of the previous data on the elderly, ”is explained. The study highlights, however, that it is “possible that the prevalence of loneliness is greater among adults over 80 or older”, which is a “consistent conclusion with previous studies, in which there was a distribution in the form of 'U' of loneliness among older adults”. More than 800 thousand deaths We are in an era where so -called social health is at risk, being considered by WHO as "a vital but often neglected, health, as essential as physical and mental health." "Social relations can reduce the risk of disease, increase life expectancy and strengthen the fabric of communities and society. Social relations improve life, giving us meaning and a feeling of belonging," it is also read, being mentioned that today loneliness affects one in six people worldwide and causes "about 871,000 deaths annually (2014-2019)". "New estimates suggest that loneliness alone may be responsible for about 871,000 deaths a year. The economic cost of these comprehensive impacts on society is just starting to be understood. Estimates suggest substantial costs for employers, health systems and individuals. Stronger social connections provide important protection in health, social and economic domains," he reads. The report points out that many of these issues only now begin to be perceived and analyzed. "This has probably been happening for years, but the pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the growing concern for digital technology has brought more attention to the issue, including governments," he is explained. The WHO also points to a correlation between poverty or low income and the feeling of loneliness. "In general, the lower the performance group in a country, the higher the loneliness rate. It is estimated that low-yielding countries have the higher (24.3 percent), followed by the medium-low yield countries (19.3 percent), medium-high performance countries (12.1 percent) and high-performance countries (10.6 percent)," can be read. Despite some worrying scenarios, WHO leaves some suggestions and even says that "there is hope" to get around the problem. "There are effective strategies for promoting social connection and these must be expanded," for example, by the "regular monitoring of the prevalence of social connection, social isolation and solitude at the global, regional and national level." This monitoring should be viewed as "a high priority", allowing "to track progress and measure the impact of strategies to deal with the issue." It is also suggested the “international development and adoption of reliable measuring instruments, interculturally valid for social connection, social isolation and loneliness”, and as a priority ”should be viewed the creation“ of an instrument to measure social connection, as conceived in this report: in the three dimensions of structure, function and quality ”. The study was based on reference documents on global and regional estimates of the prevalence of loneliness and mortality due to loneliness, “the first of this type”; a global review of political documents; Network mapping and analysis, the inclusion of 64 experiences experienced by people in relation to social connection, social isolation and loneliness, as well as “high quality evidence, prioritizing systematic revisions, meta-analysis and large-scale multinational studies”, without forgetting the experience of the WHO technical advisory group itself, “composed of 20 renowned global experts”.

item.title: China-Portuguese | Chengdu Pavilion shows Portuguese products
item.description:
In the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion venture in Chengdu, pavilions for foreign countries and entrepreneurs who want to establish business in China are installed. Portugal is also there, represented by the Portugal Pavilion, but according to manager Ângelo Sousa, there is a lack of support from the Portuguese government and strength to combat competition
“For us there are no barriers between Portugal and China. We are 365 days here and there.” This is the way the objectives of the team that is behind the Portugal Pavilion present at the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion are presented in Chengdu and which is managed by two partners: Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa. The two realized that the Shanghai zone had reached a saturation point in the trade of products and that it was necessary to go more to the interior of the country to try to sell things as Portuguese as wine, cod or olive oil. HM talked to Yinhui Tui about this project on the fringes of a lunch in Lisbon by the Friends of the New Seda Route Association, chaired by Fernanda Ilhéu. The event served precisely for Yinhui Tui to present the objectives of the Portugal Pavilion and try to capture business interests. “This is a very important market for Portuguese products. In China we have separated the country [in commercial terms] in four markets. We have the region of Beijing and Shanghai, which we call 'Yangtze River Economic Zone', and 'Pearl River Economic Zone'. The fourth zone is composed by the cities of Chengdu and Chongqing and which is a new economic area established in 2020. Portuguese have a lot of potential in these markets, ”he said. The entrepreneur recalls that the marketing of Portuguese products is still below the one that is done by French, Spanish or other countries, but when the Chinese buyer discovers wine or olive oil, he is surprised. "In Shanghai, for example, some customers already have their opinion on French or Australians. But many think that Portuguese products have more quality," said Yinhui Tui, noting that in the area where the Portugal Pavilion operates in Sichuan province, "people are a little more conservative and prefer to try, prove and feel before buying." "Our pavilion is next to the French pavilion and we often see customers opt for French wine. But when they go through our pavilion, they see our brands and ask what we have. When they realize that we have cheaper wine compared to French, they are surprised and say it is better, and then buy." This responsible explains that the population in the fourth economic zone is 130 million people, much more than the number of people living in the Iberian Peninsula. "Then I think it's a market with a lot of potential," he said. The Role of Lusosino Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa created Lusosino that it acts as the managing entity of the pavilion, which was born “with the intention of promoting Portuguese products in the Great Market of China”. Thus, there is a “showroom” of very Portuguese products, representing some brands known as is the case of Vieira crackers, Esporão wine, Sal Marnoto, the Prisca jams or Vista Alegre, among others. It is in this pavilion that "exhibitors display the best products, buyers discover trends and where they both find the conditions to realize business." Moreover, Lusosino, through this pavilion, helps Portuguese entrepreneurs in marketing campaigns and in the best way to contact potential Chinese customers. Specifically, Lusosino promises to perform “producer and brands records, commercial representation, market analysis, market support and preparation, among other services”, reads on the website. However, and according to Ângelo Freitas de Sousa to HM, there are many obstacles to putting Portuguese products in China. “[The Chengdu and Chongqing zone] has the advantage of being a growing market that is not overloaded with exporters and has no addictions as happens in the Shanghai zone. It is a very large market and where there are many producers.” By addictions, the entrepreneur refers to “competition” from other countries and buying habits of Chinese customers, who are faster looking for products from other nationalities than from Portugal. "There are habits of certain brands that are implemented and people don't even look at others or experience them." The Portuguese Pavilion project began with an idea of ​​Ângelo Ferreira de Sousa, who has a Chinese wife who helps him in the business. “I met Yinhui Tui, he liked Portuguese products, we were friends and then we ended up joining energy,” he said, explaining that the interior of the country is still knowing foreign products, not just Portuguese. "The Shanghai zone has nowhere to grow and this is a growing economic zone. There are many factories that are moving to Chengdu, so there will be more development," he said. Absence of marketing The Portuguese entrepreneur regrets that the Portuguese authorities have given little support to the project, except for any follow -up by AICEP - Agency for Investment and Foreign Trade of Portugal. "All the investment was made by us and we have not had a lot of support. We had some help from AICEP, but nothing special. We do fairs, the showrooms, to prove and know our products in major cities," said Angelo Ferreira de Sousa. The entrepreneur also regrets that, despite the list of hundreds of years between Portugal and China, there is still flaws in the commercial strategy for the export of Portuguese products in the country. "The Spaniards are much further ahead than us," he said. Regarding the role of Macao as a platform, the entrepreneur says it is equally difficult to bring products from Portugal to China or Macau to China, due to lack of customs agreements and little flexibility. "It is not because we call Macau that I can, for example, putting sausages, cod or preserves in China, or other Portuguese products. To pass from Portugal to Macau is easy, but it is no longer so easy to take after Portuguese products from Macau to China. We have not been able to do much through Macau, but we have not sought much," he said. At the presentation in Lisbon, Yinhui Tui advanced some figures behind the construction of the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion, and help to understand their size: about 70 billion euros of investment and a space of 300,000 cubic meters. The Portugal Pavilion does not only do contact sessions or fairs: if a businessman wants to leave tons of products there, he can do so. Then the pavilion is in charge of distribution through several areas of China. “In the southern market, closer to Macao, there is a lot of competition in some areas, so it should be betting inside China,” said Yinhui Tui, referring to the potential and factor novelty that exists in some areas of the country regarding commerce.
